repnme.cdata!:
Ukraine - Hydropower Rehabilitation and
            System Control Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Ukraine - Hydropower
            Rehabilitation and System Control Project was satisfactory,
            the sustainability was likely, the institutional development
            impact was modest, and the Bank and borrower performance
            were both satisfactory. The lessons learned indicated that
            it is important to have a reform-oriented government not
            only during the project preparation, but throughout the
            entire project cycle as well. The experience in Ukraine has
            shown that a reversal of the initially progressive course of
            economic reforms have adversely affected the implementation
            of the Bank's investment project. During the project
            preparation the government indicated that improving
            financial discipline in the energy sector, was a priority of
            its reform program, and the project generated specific
            pressure on the government to deliver in this regard. Cash
            collections reached their highest levels only when included
            as specific targets in the International Monetary
            Fund's Extended Fund Facility Program, and the
            Bank's Programmatic Adjustment Loan. The donors'
            working group on energy sector reforms has provided valuable
            assistance to the government's sector reform efforts.

Ukraine - Hydropower Rehabilitation and
            System Control Project

            HYDROPOWER REHABILITATION PROJECT,TF038843-UKRAINE - HYDROPOWER PROJECT - EC,TF038608-UKRAINE:  HYDROPOWER PROJECT,TF040867-UKRAINE: HYDROPOWER REHABILITATION

repnme.cdata!:
Ukraine - Hydropower Rehabilitation and
            System Control Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Hydropower
            Rehabilitation and System Control Project are to: a) improve
            the efficiency, reliability, safety and environmental
            performance of hydropower plants; b) increase hydropower
            generation capacity; c) improve the quality of electricity
            supply by upgrading load and frequency control; and d)
            reduce fuel costs by facilitating the economic dispatch of
            generating units. The project includes the following
            components: 1) implementation of the complete rehabilitation
            program for the Dnieper I and II hydropower plants and the
            Kiev pump storage plant (PSP); near-complete implementation
            of the rehabilitation program for the Kakhovka hydropower
            station (HPS); and partial implementation of the
            rehabilitation program for the Kiev, Kanev, Kremenchug and
            Dniprodzerzhinsk hydropower plants; 2) installation of dam
            safety monitoring systems at the main water reservoirs on
            the Dnieper river; 3) upgrade of communications, dispatch,
            system control and protection, and generating unit control;
            and 4) technical assistance for project implementation, and
            optimization of the use of the reservoirs on the Dnieper river.

Ukraine - Hydropower Rehabilitation and
